sourceDesc.p: This is a born digital document. All sources used in compiling and collected the data are cated in the bibliographic sections of the respective entry / element.

revisionDesc.change: Added nav link goto:{@xml:id} to XSLT. This allows to navigate from XSLT to XML editor.
Added visualisation of examples to XSLT
Made xPath (elementPath) for feature selection generic, added "contains": //tei:fvLib[contains(@xml:id,'_values')]/tei:fs
Added @xml:id on featureRealisation: this is needed to navigate in HTML output
reworked example: * proposed renaming of "occurence" to "featureRealisation" * made
reworked examples based on last meeting: * tentatively added f[@name="explanation"] to featureValues
converted data to new schema version
Conversion from fs schema to new schema

item.label: k → affrication (in the environment of anterior vowel) /ć/
k → affrication (in the environment of anterior vowel) /č/

div.p: Uvular realisation is preserved in MSA loanwords, ex. taqrīban «approximately», qarīban «soon» and in some Turkish loanwords, ex. qawūn «melon» and by young speakers often in words realized with /g/ or /ǧ/ by older speakers, ex. gidīm or ǧidim - qadīm «old», gilīl or ǧilīl - qalīl «few, little» ; Devoicing of /g/ to /k/ in contact with /t/, ex. k-t-l (which sometimes becomes affricated in the environment of an anterior vowel c-t-l)

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Exception: čān - yikūn; there is desaffrication when in contact with coronal consonants [d], [t], [ḏ], [t],̱ [t]̣ et [ḏ̣ ]
čān - yikūn; ʾabū-k «ton père (m.)» et ʾabū-č«ton père (f.); [k] is reestablished in the passive participles of verbs C-C-k of scheme *maC1C2ūC3 (ex. manyūk, maʿlūk et mahlūk)
vestigial variants: čīl "measure, weight", yčammilen "they (f.) complete", čänna "daughter in law", etc.
It is a recessive feature
k to x: lexically restricted spirantization: xtar 'more', but not *xtir, but ktir 'much'
/k/ in Kormakiti has the palatal and veralallophonic variants /k'/ and /k/ before front and non-front vowels respectively

cit.note: With regards to the example, the /l/ 'is assimilated to a following /k/ in bikkill - bilkill (with vowel harmony). This is a recent change as previous dialectologists do not record this assimilation in the same word

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Exception:the pronominal suffix of the second person singular feminine may be an affricate č (as noted in Poesies Fezzanaises)
There was nothing concrete about the reflex of /k/ in the chapter regarding al-Khums, but in the examples /k/ is always reflected as it is
ḳ and k are heard and all have a minimal pair showing phonemic opposition bētuḳ “your (sg. masc.) house” – bētik “your (sg. Fem.) house”
ḳ and k are heard and all have a minimal pair showing phonemic opposition bētuḳ “your (sg. masc.) house” – bētik “your (sg. Fem.) house”
ḳ and k are heard and all have a minimal pair showing phonemic opposition bētuḳ “your (sg. masc.) house” – bētik “your (sg. Fem.) house”
ḳ and k are heard and all have a minimal pair showing phonemic opposition bētuḳ “your (sg. masc.) house” – bētik “your (sg. Fem.) house”
ḳ and k are heard and all have a minimal pair showing phonemic opposition bētuḳ “your (sg. masc.) house” – bētik “your (sg. Fem.) house”
ḳ and k are heard and all have a minimal pair showing phonemic opposition bētuḳ “your (sg. masc.) house” – bētik “your (sg. Fem.) house”
ḳ and k are heard and all have a minimal pair showing phonemic opposition bētuḳ “your (sg. masc.) house” – bētik “your (sg. Fem.) house”
ḳ and k are heard, true phonemic opposition in a minimal pair īduḳ “your (sg. masc.) hand” – īdik “your (sg. fem.) hand”
ḳ and k are heard, a true phonemic opposition seams to be developing
/k/ is realized as the affricate [č] in contact with /i/ by some speakers, probably due to influence from the Eastern part of the peninsula
affrication seems to be at least partly lexically conditioned, as in čānūn, "portable hearth"
note that Young did not transcribe from recordings, but by ear
